body:
I waited a while but thought it's better to proceed now and continue to gradually improving.

My base idea at participating in this issue is create a gradle build that equivalent of an ant build. I believe this way will be able to easily apply to the other nice idea(collect all of the jars to one place or some substitution of ant build's part)

I was sure that all of schema and file name to match.
hmm... managed to force-push this branch to my fork when fixing up my repo following a mishap.  so this PR is now closed and I'll open a new one for this.

I think the wsclient/websockets jar differences are OK.
I think the fvt/svt jar differences are OK.
I agree that working on the console.war (really want it in two locations?) and other work to consolidate jar location can be done after this is merged.

Sorry for late. I will keep in mind your mention about QUARKS-152 :)
But due to business trip, I'll start again this issue in this thursday

Client code needs the control Id for example to unregister controls of closed jobs.  Retrieving the id from the control's implementation works for JSON controls, by forcing a cast from the control's MBean interface to its implementation class. It does not work for JMX controls where beans are, I believe, dynamic proxies to the implementation.  So the considered options were:
- ControlService.getControlId() - get the control id given its name, type, and interface.  Use the id to unregister the control.
- JobMXBean.getControlId() - didn't seem the right choice as the control Id is unrelated to the bean, beanc may not be necessarily registered with a ControlService, etc.

@ddebrunner , @dlaboss - any thoughts?
Is this a WIP?
@ddebrunner Yes, still a WIP. I plan to execute more tests to see if more changes need to be made.

- I could not find a function that corresponds to `excludepackagenames` of ant-javadoc.
  I tried to using `exclude` to remove the runtime packages, but the results did not inherit the javadoc of interface.
  `excludepackagenames` removes the selected packages in the final output.(See [Javadoc Task](https://ant.apache.org/manual/Tasks/javadoc.html))
- So I could not be applied to `excludepackagenames` feature. As a result, runtime packages are included in the javadoc, ant this will be removed later.
- Some error occurs when there is no Xdoclint:none option. I added Xdoclint:none again and will register a new jira issue for resolve these errors.
unrelated test failure (QUARKS-219).  closing/reopening to rerun

After 3 travis-ci attempts I surrender.  The new tests in StatisticsTest pass for me so I'm merging this.

Noticed there was an old quarks-edge reference which is now edgent-edge.
What's the appropiate value for this manifest attr? (this is in common-build.xml)

```
            <attribute name="Implementation-Vendor" value="edgent-edge@github.com"/>
```

Answered my own question... I see the gradle scripts use "Apache Software Foundation".

-1

Top level package should be `org.apache.edgent`, not just `edgent`.

We had postponed moving to org.apache until the name was settled, now the name is assumed to be settled we should have a single change to `org.apache.edgent`.
now you tell me :-)
@dlaboss Sorry, thought it was well known that the package names would be `org.apache.something` ...

@ddebrunner no worries. I just forgot.  Unless I hear otherwise, I'm leaving the jars with the simple "edgent." prefix (e.g., edgent.providers.direct.jar).
Ditto for ApplicationService ALIAS, SYSTEM_APP_PREFIX,
IotDevice RESERVED_ID_PREFIX, 
PublishSubscribe RESERVED_TOPIC_PREFIX
@dlaboss For the jar names I would follow what most Apache projects do. Haven't looked yet, but I seem to remember org.apache in the names
My veto is lifted since the package names are now org.apache.*

A quick sampling of other projects (Hadoop, Hive, Derby, Kafka) shows an absence of org.apache in jar names.  

That said, http://incubator.apache.org/guides/release-java.html#best-practice-jars has a "TODO" that seems to indicate apache should be in the name.

So do we want "apache.edgent" as the prefix for our jar names?  Need a decision ASAP.
@dlaboss Yeah, I'd thought it was common to have org.apache in the jar names, but the majority I see are also without that. I think I was remembering org.eclipse jars.

Hi @ddebrunner :)
How about modify `include 'connectors:iotf' -> include 'connectors:iotp'` in settings.gradle
I checked it works in Linux/OSX include all junit testcase
Thanks @Cazen , that fixed it.

On timed batch:

I think part of my concern is that the api is meant to separate out what defines the window contents (TWindow) from how it is processed (methods on TWindow). 

timedBatch seems to be mixing the concepts of what is contained in the window and when it is processed, by say evicting tuples in last(10) window after a second, so that the contents of the window no longer match its definition.

It seems that it's really trying to define a window like:

`last(long period, TimeUnit unit, int max)`

where the contents of the window is the last `period` seconds with a maximum of the `max` most recent tuples.

Then batch is applied to this window as normal.

Maybe a better question for `timedBatch(3, SECONDS, func)`, is when would it be used over

`last(3, SECONDS).batch(func)`

?

@ddebrunner , things don't build in my eclipse workspace after a rebase that includes these changes.  `samples/.classpath` has a residual `iotf` in an excluding statement for range sensor.  Hence eclipse tries to build the `samples/scenarios/iotp/range/sensor` code and fails (due to the absence of pi4j in my environment).

It looks some gradle and jacoco version can cause conflict.
(I found some similar case from googling. Please refer to: [link1](https://discuss.gradle.org/t/jacoco-coverage-for-android-test-cases-fails-in-gradle-version-2-13-and-2-14/18272/7), [link2](https://www.mkyong.com/gradle/gradle-jacoco-incompatible-version-1006/)
Thanks! Yes, it was a version issue.  I just need to use `./gradlew` (v2.13) instead of my `gradle` (v2.10)
I like this. Wanted this so badly that i wrote Maven pom's for every piece to build the project with. :(

@dlaboss  I made an update on my repo to 1) delete the use of getDate 2) use build_version instead of a separate variable 3) change the group id and artifacts id (using the unified groupid and move the diff part to artifacts) eg. edgent.apps:iot  => org.apache.edgent:apps.iot. This solves the artifacts name conflicts like there are multiple "graph" and "topology" in api & spi.
Going to merge this (thanks again) and will tweak afterwards.

An unrelated test failure.  Looks like a timing sensitivity in IotProviderTest.  Creating a Jira for it.
Trying close/reopen to cycle again.

wondering... did you consider omitting the "org.apache.edgent" or such?  Probably 99% of all oplets will be edgent oplets so the prefix is really just undesired noise imo.
Related, an oplet with a long package name (e.g., TextFileReader; can see with scripts/connectors/file sample) runs off the right edge of the box; and there isn't a right edge drawn on my mac -- that's w/o this PR's changes.

That is certainly an option.  My thoughts were that if someone had a package that was not org.apache.edgent that I the legend box would need to accommodate that length anyway.

If folks think that it is more desirable to remove org.apache.edgent then it can be done.

Cheers,

Susan

@dlaboss, if a stream has multiple tags, all of the tags will appear in the table cell. If there are multiple streams, each with multiple tags, then all of the tags associated with the streams wll be displayed. I attached images to the JIRA issue.

Sigh.. this ci failure was on the java7 run of HttpGlobalTest (part of test7.run target).  All of java8 build/test/release processing prior to that were successful.  As that test uses the public http://httpbin.org web-server, maybe there was just a hickup with it. Clearly the changes in this PR have nothing to do with that so IMO don't feel compelled to await a clean ci run before merging.

+1 The new `servlets/LICENSE` and change to `/LICENSE`.

Since `servlets/LICENSE` has the URLs to the corresponding licenses, add a http URL for the MIT license (`https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT`) and remove all of the *.LICENSE files under js/ext.

How does that sound?  (sorry for previously asking to add the MIT license file to the repo)

That is fine.  I'll do this:

2) Only point to the licenses via the http URL

Susan

Found it, https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/EDGENT-377

I think I should be able to use/implement an IoTGateway without having to have `IoTDevice` instances for each connected device.

As an example the gateway may already be routing device events/commands as part of its core functionality so I don't need connectivity in Edgent to the devices, instead I just want to write an analytics app that analyzes the events/ commands going through the gateway.

The use of IotDevice instances in an IotGateway context was to preserve / extend the existing API model - an IotDevice represents a particular IoT device and you use an instance of it to publish events / subscribe to commands for a specific IoT device.

Youd use IotGateway.getIotDevice() to get an IotDevice for a particular connected device and then just use it as you would in a non-gateway context.

Sounds like you prefer an alternate model for the gateway context that only uses a simple device-identifier string and events/commands methods that take explicit device-ids as arguments.

```
IotGateway extends IotDevice {
  commandsForDevice(device-id, )  // cant be 	commands(device-id-string, )
  commandsForDevice(Set<device-id>, )  // empty set -> no filtering / include all? gateway too?
  commandsForType(type-id, )
  eventsForDevice(device-id, TStream,)
  eventsForDevice(device-id-fn, TStream, event-id-fn,)

  String getDeviceId(Map<String,String> impl-device-id-attrs)
  String getDeviceType(String deviceId)
}
```
Does that capture it?  I can live with that.

Probably doesnt change your mind about but I noticed an omission in the original proposal for publishing device specific events from a multi-device stream:
      `events(Function<JsonObject,IotDevice> device-id-fn, TStream<JsonObject>, )`

No, that's not what I meant. 

I meant that I should be able to use a gateway, without having to create IoTDevices to perform analytics on connected device events/commands. Say I don't want to interact with the devices, just analyze what is going on with them.

Sorry, I'm not following you.  It may have been clear to all but just to be sure... I've only been talking about an Edgent app on a gateway device _as a client of the IoT hub_ - how the gateway app publishes events to the hub as if they were from a "connected device" (a device serviced by the gateway) and how the gateway app receives commands from the hub that are for a connected device.  

IotGateway.getIotDevice(...) wouldn't/shouldn't engage in any conversation with the hub.  It just gives the gateway app a handle representing the connected device's identity (which can be accessed via IotDevice.getDeviceId()) and the ability to publish events and/or to subscribe to events for that device.

(Additionally, a gateway / the gateway app can publish device events to the hub from "the gateway device id" and subscribe to device commands for "the gateway device id".)

This topic/feature doesn't say anything about interactions from an Edgent gateway app with the gateway's connected devices.

Where does that leave us?  Is the original proposal satisfactory for the above?  Please elaborate on the scenario you're talking about, how it's not satisfied by the above, what specific changes to the proposal are needed to address it.  Thanks!  
(made updates that may or may not address your concerns :-) You may want to checkout how things look now)
Lacking any further feedback / comments I went ahead with an implementation.
looks like travis may be wedged. closing / reopening to try to clear things up.

@johnament thanks for the contribution!

I'm pretty ignorant about uploading things to mavencentral so I've got questions.
(Note my code review question and the "signAll" task).

Where's the ASF policy doc on it?
What testing has / can been done to verify the changes?

I ran publishToMavenLocal (without these changes) and noticed that source jars also get put in the repository.  I also noticed that those source jars lack META-INF/LICENSE and NOTICE. Previously not an issue because publishToMavenLocal didn't publish to some public repo.  I'm also not sure the generated POMs are correct.  While the poms do include decls for external dependencies, they lack dependency specs for other Edgent jars (that were expressed in the build.gradle files and ultimately captured in the MANIFEST.MF/Class-Path of the binary jars).

We have a small amount of documentation for [Publish to a Maven Repository](https://github.com/apache/incubator-edgent/blob/master/DEVELOPMENT.md#publish-to-maven-repository)  Could you enhance that to cover these new non-local publish capabilities?  (the setup details and what gradle task to use for the local publish.  Is it really just the "my ASF credentials" that are needed?)

Once the additional details are present the [RM guide doc](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/EDGENT/Release+Manager%27s+Guide#ReleaseManager'sGuide-TaggingandPublishingtheRelease) needs to be updated as well.  I'm happy to do that once all of the "how to use" info is in place.

On Mon, May 22, 2017 at 3:49 PM Dale LaBossiere <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> @johnament <https://github.com/johnament> thanks for the contribution!
>
> I'm pretty ignorant about uploading things to mavencentral so I've got
> questions.
> (Note my code review question and the "signAll" task).
>

I have many questions about this area, and was planning to start a separate
discussion thread.  I suspect you may have been doing it the hard way.


> Do these changes do all that's required to meet the ASF policies for
> publishing to mavencentral? What testing has / can been done to verify the
> changes?
>

The ASF has no such policies.  We provide for it at an infrastructure level
but that's it.  The default binary expectations apply.

I've tested it locally by publishing to a local maven repo.  Its not a
perfect test since my local maven repo is just an http server.


> What testing has been done to verify these changes do everything that's
> required? Can you
>
> (e.g., can you build an Edgent application using maven?) Both upload and
> testing that a client can build using mavencentral artifacts. Exactly what
> artifacts are uploaded? What does the pom look like?
>

There's an open request with infra to create your staging area.  Once thats
been done we can start talking about CI including pushes to ASF's internal
nexus instances.  We would only push to maven central during a release,
hence why the URLs are different.

To be honest, this isn't meant to be a one and done type of change, we'll
need to refine the release process a bit to clean up some of the issues, so
I actually suspect this to be 1st of N pull requests on this JIRA.


> We have a small amount of documentation for Publish to a Maven Repository
> <https://github.com/apache/incubator-edgent/blob/master/DEVELOPMENT.md#publish-to-maven-repository>
> Could you enhance that to cover these new non-local publish capabilities?
> (the setup details and what gradle task to use for the local publish. Is it
> really just the "my ASF credentials" that are needed?)
>

Yep, I can do that.  Though I'm not sure where that task name came from
(while gradle is beautiful tool, its sometimes very black magic to me).


> Once the additional details are present the RM guide doc
> <https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/EDGENT/Release+Manager%27s+Guide#ReleaseManager'sGuide-TaggingandPublishingtheRelease>
> needs to be updated as well. I'm happy to do that once all of the "how to
> use" info is in place.
>

Re: _I have many questions about this area, and was planning to start a separate
discussion thread.  I suspect you may have been doing it the hard way.
...
To be honest, this isn't meant to be a one and done type of change, we'll
need to refine the release process a bit to clean up some of the issues, so
I actually suspect this to be 1st of N pull requests on this JIRA._

IMO we don't want to merge a PR if it breaks the current release process and we don't yet have all the pieces in place to replace it.  Want to avoid being in a "can't make a release" state.
Please change "/target" to "target/" in the top level `.gitignore`.  `git status` is showing the per-module generated artifacts. Thanks!

With the merge from upstream, in the top level pom.xml's java7 Profile (and retrolambda config), can the following now be removed?

```
line 565
    <configuration>
      <defaultMethods>true</defaultMethods>
    </configuration>
```
unrelated test failed.  try rerun (close/open)
Type= jar is the default. So if you omit the type, that's what have will use. So a type declaration would be redundant.

Thanks for your contribution! It looks sensible to me, though wish there were some test for it. I see this whole area is lacking in that regard.  I trust you've used it successfully?  @vdogaru can you give it a quick check pls.

Yes, I believe it is sensible too. Did the initial tests on my local machine (MacOS), then performed directly on Raspberry Pi. It worked as expected. ([Imagens](https://www.dropbox.com/sh/21b1lm3khn3ppc8/AACkqro0CSfFT43soh82k8t2a?dl=0))
I believe that improvements in file formatting are needed.

Needing help in this test I am at your disposal.
